batch.name: Campbell Ch 20: DNA Tools and Biotechnology (Olympiad)
batch.description: Olympiad-level questions on DNA tools, biotechnology, recombinant DNA technology, PCR, sequencing, CRISPR, genomics, and bioethics from Campbell Biology Chapter 20
batch.subject: Biology

questions.question: A researcher wants to clone a 3.5 kb human gene into a plasmid vector. After restriction digestion of both the insert and vector with EcoRI, the researcher notices low cloning efficiency. What is the most likely cause?
options: Self-ligation of the linearized vector is more likely than insert ligation, as vector ends are compatible
EcoRI produces blunt ends that are inefficient for ligation
The 3.5 kb insert is too large for any plasmid vector
EcoRI does not cut human DNA
questions.explanation: When both vector and insert are cut with the same restriction enzyme (EcoRI, which produces 5'-AATT-3' sticky ends), vector self-ligation (re-circularization without insert) competes with insert-vector ligation. Since self-ligation is an intramolecular reaction favored at low DNA concentrations, it often dominates over the bimolecular insert-vector ligation. Solutions include: (1) dephosphorylating the vector with alkaline phosphatase (prevents self-ligation), (2) using two different restriction enzymes for directional cloning (incompatible ends prevent self-ligation), or (3) blue-white screening to identify recombinant clones. EcoRI produces 4-base 5' sticky ends, not blunt ends.

questions.question: In the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), what is the purpose of the denaturation step at 94-98°C?
options: To activate the DNA polymerase
To synthesize new DNA strands
To anneal primers to the template
To separate the double-stranded DNA template into single strands
questions.explanation: The denaturation step (typically 94-98°C for 15-30 seconds) disrupts the hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs, separating the double-stranded DNA template into two single strands. This exposes the template sequences so primers can bind (anneal) during the subsequent lower-temperature step. Taq polymerase (from Thermus aquaticus) is already active and thermostable; the denaturation step does not activate it. Annealing occurs at 50-65°C, and extension (DNA synthesis) occurs at 72°C—the optimal temperature for Taq polymerase.

questions.question: CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing requires two components: the Cas9 endonuclease and a guide RNA (gRNA). What determines the specificity of CRISPR-Cas9 targeting?
options: The 20-nucleotide spacer sequence in the gRNA that is complementary to the target DNA, adjacent to a PAM sequence
The Cas9 protein recognizes specific DNA sequences directly
The size of the target gene determines specificity
Random binding of Cas9 to any double-stranded DNA
questions.explanation: CRISPR-Cas9 targeting specificity is determined by two elements: (1) the 20-nucleotide spacer sequence in the guide RNA (gRNA) that base-pairs with the complementary target DNA strand, and (2) the presence of a protospacer adjacent motif (PAM, typically 5'-NGG-3' for SpCas9) immediately downstream of the target site on the non-target strand. The Cas9 protein first recognizes the PAM, then checks for complementarity between the gRNA and the adjacent DNA. Mismatches in the 'seed region' (8-12 nt proximal to the PAM) are least tolerated. Off-target cutting can occur at sites with partial gRNA complementarity, which is a major concern for therapeutic applications.

questions.question: Sanger sequencing (chain termination method) uses dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs). Why do ddNTPs cause chain termination?
options: They are toxic to DNA polymerase, causing it to dissociate
They cause the DNA template to denature
They are too large to fit in the active site of DNA polymerase
They lack a 3'-OH group, preventing formation of the phosphodiester bond with the next incoming nucleotide
questions.explanation: Dideoxynucleotides (2',3'-dideoxynucleotides, ddNTPs) lack the 3'-hydroxyl group that is essential for forming the 3'-5' phosphodiester bond with the next nucleotide. When DNA polymerase incorporates a ddNTP instead of the normal dNTP, the growing chain cannot be extended further because there is no 3'-OH to attack the 5' phosphate of the incoming nucleotide. By including a small proportion of each fluorescently labeled ddNTP (ddATP, ddGTP, ddCTP, ddTTP) along with normal dNTPs, chain termination occurs randomly at every position, producing fragments of every possible length that reveal the DNA sequence when separated by capillary electrophoresis.

questions.question: A gel electrophoresis experiment separates DNA fragments. Fragment A is 500 bp, Fragment B is 2,000 bp, and Fragment C is 1,000 bp. The gel is run with the negative electrode at the top and positive electrode at the bottom. In what order do the fragments appear from top (near wells) to bottom?
options: All fragments migrate the same distance
questions.explanation: DNA is negatively charged (due to phosphate groups) and migrates toward the positive electrode (anode) during electrophoresis. Smaller fragments migrate faster through the gel matrix pores than larger fragments. Therefore, from top (near wells) to bottom: the largest fragment B (2,000 bp) travels the shortest distance, followed by C (1,000 bp), and the smallest fragment A (500 bp) travels the farthest. This inverse relationship between fragment size and migration distance is the basis for size determination using molecular weight markers (ladders). The relationship between log(size) and distance migrated is approximately linear over a range of fragment sizes.

questions.question: A researcher wants to detect a specific mRNA transcript in tissue sections while preserving spatial information about which cells express the gene. Which technique should they use?
options: Northern blot
RT-PCR
In situ hybridization (ISH)
Western blot
questions.explanation: In situ hybridization (ISH) uses labeled nucleic acid probes (DNA or RNA) that hybridize to complementary mRNA sequences directly within intact tissue sections or whole-mount specimens. This preserves spatial information, showing exactly which cells and tissues express the gene of interest. Northern blots detect mRNA but require tissue homogenization (losing spatial information). RT-PCR quantifies mRNA levels but also requires homogenized samples. Western blots detect protein, not mRNA. Fluorescent ISH (FISH) variants and single-molecule FISH (smFISH) can visualize individual mRNA molecules within cells with high spatial resolution.

questions.question: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies like Illumina sequencing differ from Sanger sequencing in a fundamental way. What is the key difference that enables massively parallel sequencing?
options: NGS uses longer reads than Sanger sequencing
NGS sequences millions of short DNA fragments simultaneously on a flow cell surface, rather than sequencing one fragment at a time
NGS does not require any DNA preparation
NGS uses radioactive rather than fluorescent labels
questions.explanation: The revolutionary aspect of NGS is massively parallel sequencing—millions to billions of DNA fragments are sequenced simultaneously. In Illumina sequencing: (1) DNA is fragmented and adapters are ligated; (2) fragments are bridge-amplified on a flow cell to create clusters of identical molecules; (3) fluorescently labeled reversible terminators allow one base to be incorporated and read per cycle across all clusters simultaneously. While individual reads are shorter than Sanger reads (typically 150-300 bp vs. 700-1000 bp for Sanger), the massive parallelism generates gigabases of data per run, enabling whole-genome sequencing at a fraction of the cost.

questions.question: Restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLPs) were among the first DNA markers used for genetic mapping and forensics. What creates an RFLP between two individuals?
options: Differences in DNA fragment size due to mutations that create or destroy restriction enzyme recognition sites, or insertions/deletions between sites
Differences in protein expression between individuals
Differences in RNA splicing patterns
Differences in chromosome number
questions.explanation: RFLPs arise from DNA sequence variations that alter restriction enzyme recognition sites or change the distance between sites. A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) within a restriction site can abolish the site, creating a larger uncut fragment. Alternatively, insertions, deletions, or variable number tandem repeats (VNTRs) between two sites change the fragment length without altering the sites themselves. RFLPs are detected by restriction digestion followed by gel electrophoresis and Southern blotting. While largely replaced by STR profiling and SNP genotyping, RFLPs were foundational in the development of genetic mapping and forensic DNA profiling.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine the function of a newly identified gene in mice. Which approach would provide the most definitive evidence of gene function?
options: Creating a knockout mouse by disrupting the gene using CRISPR-Cas9 and analyzing the mutant phenotype
Comparing the gene's sequence to known genes in databases (homology search)
Performing Northern blot to determine where the gene is expressed
Predicting protein structure using computational tools
questions.explanation: Creating a knockout (loss-of-function) organism by disrupting or deleting the gene provides the most direct evidence of gene function. If removing a gene causes a specific phenotype (e.g., developmental defect, disease, behavioral change), this directly links the gene to that function. CRISPR-Cas9 has made gene knockout much faster and more precise than traditional methods (homologous recombination with targeting vectors). Complementary approaches include: rescue experiments (restoring the gene corrects the phenotype), conditional knockouts (tissue-specific or temporal inactivation), and knock-in experiments. While homology searches, expression analysis, and computational predictions provide important information, they cannot definitively establish function—only perturbation experiments can.

questions.question: In DNA fingerprinting (STR profiling), short tandem repeats (STRs) are amplified by PCR. A forensic sample from a crime scene shows alleles of 12 and 14 repeats at the D13S317 locus. A suspect shows 12 and 12 at the same locus. Can the suspect be excluded as the source?
options: Yes, the suspect can be definitively excluded because the alleles do not match
Yes, because forensic DNA must show exact matches at all loci
The STR evidence is inconclusive regardless of the results
No, the suspect cannot be excluded—they share one allele (12), and the other allele (14) could have come from a different contributor if this is a mixed sample
questions.explanation: The suspect (12,12 homozygote) shares one allele (12) with the evidence sample (12,14). If the evidence is a single-source sample, the suspect can be excluded because they lack the 14-repeat allele. However, if the evidence could be a mixture of DNA from two or more individuals (common at crime scenes), the suspect cannot be excluded—the 12 allele could be from the suspect and the 14 from another contributor. This illustrates why forensic DNA interpretation requires careful consideration of mixture possibilities, and why multiple STR loci (typically 20+ in modern kits) are analyzed to achieve extremely high discriminating power. The random match probability for 20+ STR loci is typically less than 1 in a trillion.

questions.question: Quantitative PCR (qPCR or real-time PCR) measures DNA amplification in real time. What is the Ct (threshold cycle) value, and how does it relate to the initial amount of target DNA?
options: Ct is the total number of PCR cycles; higher Ct means more initial DNA
Ct is the cycle at which the reaction reaches plateau phase
Ct is the cycle at which fluorescence first exceeds a threshold; lower Ct values indicate more initial template DNA
Ct is unrelated to the initial amount of DNA
questions.explanation: The Ct (threshold cycle) or Cq (quantification cycle) value is the PCR cycle number at which the fluorescent signal first crosses a defined threshold above background. Because PCR amplification is exponential during the log-linear phase, samples with more initial template DNA reach the threshold in fewer cycles (lower Ct), while samples with less template require more cycles (higher Ct). A difference of one Ct value represents approximately a 2-fold difference in initial template quantity (since each PCR cycle doubles the DNA). Ct values are used to calculate relative gene expression (ΔΔCt method) or absolute quantification using standard curves.

questions.question: Southern blotting is used to detect specific DNA sequences. What is the correct order of steps in a Southern blot?
options: DNA extraction → restriction digestion → gel electrophoresis → transfer to membrane → hybridization with labeled probe → detection
Protein extraction → gel electrophoresis → antibody probing
RNA extraction → reverse transcription → gel electrophoresis → probe hybridization
Cell lysis → immunoprecipitation → mass spectrometry
questions.explanation: The Southern blot (invented by Edwin Southern, 1975) follows this sequence: (1) Isolate genomic DNA and digest with restriction enzymes. (2) Separate fragments by agarose gel electrophoresis. (3) Denature DNA in the gel (alkali treatment). (4) Transfer (blot) DNA fragments to a nylon or nitrocellulose membrane by capillary action or vacuum. (5) Fix DNA to membrane (UV crosslinking or baking). (6) Hybridize with a labeled DNA or RNA probe complementary to the target sequence. (7) Wash away unbound probe. (8) Detect signal (autoradiography for radioactive probes, or chemiluminescence). Northern blotting is the analogous technique for RNA, and Western blotting detects proteins using antibodies.

questions.question: Gene therapy aims to correct genetic diseases by introducing functional copies of defective genes. Which vector is most commonly used for in vivo gene therapy, and why?
options: Naked plasmid DNA, because it is easy to produce
Adeno-associated virus (AAV), because it has low immunogenicity, can infect dividing and non-dividing cells, and rarely integrates into the genome
Bacteriophage lambda, because it efficiently infects human cells
Retrovirus, because it always integrates at safe genomic locations
questions.explanation: Adeno-associated virus (AAV) has become the preferred vector for in vivo gene therapy because: (1) low immunogenicity—minimal immune response compared to adenovirus; (2) broad tissue tropism—different AAV serotypes can target different tissues (AAV9 for CNS, AAV8 for liver); (3) ability to infect non-dividing cells (unlike retrovirus/lentivirus for some applications); (4) predominantly remains episomal (does not integrate into the host genome, reducing insertional mutagenesis risk); (5) long-term stable expression in non-dividing cells. Limitations include small packaging capacity (~4.7 kb), potential for pre-existing antibodies in patients, and the episomal nature means expression may be lost in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.question: A researcher performs a restriction digest with BamHI (recognition site: 5'-GGATCC-3') on a 10 kb circular plasmid and obtains two linear fragments of 3 kb and 7 kb. How many BamHI sites are present in this plasmid?
questions.explanation: Cutting a circular DNA molecule with a restriction enzyme always produces a number of fragments equal to the number of cut sites. Since two fragments were produced (3 kb + 7 kb = 10 kb total, consistent with the plasmid size), there must be exactly 2 BamHI sites in the plasmid. One cut in a circle produces a single linear fragment; two cuts produce two fragments; n cuts produce n fragments. This is different from linear DNA, where n cuts produce n+1 fragments. The result is consistent because 3 + 7 = 10 kb, matching the original plasmid size.

questions.question: RNA interference (RNAi) can be used to study gene function by knocking down gene expression. Which enzyme processes double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) into short interfering RNAs (siRNAs)?
options: RNA polymerase II
Dicer (an RNase III family endoribonuclease)
Reverse transcriptase
DNA ligase
questions.explanation: Dicer is the key enzyme that initiates the RNAi pathway by cleaving long double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) or pre-miRNA hairpins into 21-23 nucleotide short interfering RNAs (siRNAs) or mature miRNAs. Dicer is an RNase III family enzyme with a PAZ domain (that binds the dsRNA end), two RNase III catalytic domains (that make staggered cuts), and a helicase domain. The resulting siRNAs have 2-nucleotide 3' overhangs and 5' phosphates. One strand (the guide strand) is loaded into the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC), where it directs Argonaute protein to complementary mRNA targets for degradation or translational repression.

questions.question: A bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) can carry inserts of approximately what size range, making it useful for genomic library construction?
options: 1-5 Mb
questions.explanation: BACs (Bacterial Artificial Chromosomes) can carry DNA inserts of approximately 100-300 kb, making them essential for constructing genomic libraries and genome sequencing projects. BACs are based on the F (fertility) plasmid of E. coli, which naturally maintains itself at one copy per cell, ensuring insert stability. For comparison: plasmids typically carry 0.1-10 kb inserts; cosmids 35-45 kb; fosmids ~40 kb; and YACs (Yeast Artificial Chromosomes) 200-2,000 kb but with higher chimeric rates. BACs were the primary cloning vector used in the Human Genome Project due to their stability, large insert capacity, and ease of manipulation.

questions.question: In a cDNA library construction, what is the role of reverse transcriptase?
options: To amplify DNA fragments by PCR
To ligate DNA fragments into vectors
To synthesize a DNA copy (first-strand cDNA) from mRNA templates using an oligo-dT primer
To denature double-stranded DNA
questions.explanation: Reverse transcriptase (RT) synthesizes a complementary DNA (cDNA) strand using mRNA as a template. In cDNA library construction: (1) mRNA is isolated from cells (typically using oligo-dT columns that bind poly-A tails); (2) oligo-dT primers anneal to the poly-A tail of mRNA; (3) reverse transcriptase extends the primer, synthesizing first-strand cDNA; (4) the mRNA is removed (using RNase H); (5) DNA polymerase synthesizes the second strand; (6) double-stranded cDNA is cloned into vectors. cDNA libraries represent only expressed genes (no introns, no intergenic DNA), making them valuable for identifying protein-coding sequences and studying gene expression patterns.

questions.question: The Human Genome Project (completed 2003) revealed approximately how many protein-coding genes in the human genome?
options: Approximately 100,000 genes
Approximately 20,000-25,000 genes
Approximately 5,000 genes
Approximately 500,000 genes
questions.explanation: The Human Genome Project revealed approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes (current estimates are ~19,000-20,000), far fewer than the 100,000 genes originally predicted. This was surprising because: (1) the nematode C. elegans has ~20,000 genes and many other organisms have similar gene counts, suggesting increased complexity doesn't simply require more genes; (2) much of human genome complexity arises from alternative splicing (one gene producing multiple protein variants), regulatory complexity, and non-coding RNAs; (3) protein-coding sequences represent only ~1.5% of the human genome, with the remainder consisting of introns, regulatory regions, repetitive elements, and other non-coding sequences.

questions.question: A pharmaceutical company wants to produce human insulin using recombinant DNA technology. What is the key challenge in producing functional human insulin in E. coli, and how is it addressed?
options: E. coli cannot transcribe human genes at all
E. coli produces too much insulin, causing cell death
Human insulin is toxic to E. coli
E. coli lacks the post-translational processing machinery to form disulfide bonds and cleave proinsulin, so the A and B chains are produced separately and then combined in vitro
questions.explanation: Producing functional human insulin in E. coli faces several challenges: (1) E. coli lacks eukaryotic protein processing—insulin is naturally synthesized as preproinsulin, which is processed by signal peptidase and prohormone convertases in the ER and Golgi, and folded with specific disulfide bonds. (2) E. coli cannot perform these post-translational modifications. Solution: the A chain (21 amino acids) and B chain (30 amino acids) are produced separately as fusion proteins in E. coli, purified, and then combined in vitro under conditions that promote correct disulfide bond formation (two inter-chain and one intra-chain disulfide bond). Alternatively, proinsulin can be produced and enzymatically processed in vitro. This was among the first therapeutic proteins produced by recombinant DNA technology (approved 1982).

questions.question: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size. In a standard agarose gel, which percentage of agarose would be most appropriate for resolving DNA fragments in the 100-500 bp range?
options: 0.5% agarose
2.0% agarose
0.8% agarose
4.0% agarose
questions.explanation: The agarose concentration determines pore size and thus the resolution range. Higher agarose concentrations have smaller pores that better resolve small fragments: 0.5% agarose: resolves 1-30 kb fragments; 0.8% agarose: resolves 0.5-12 kb; 1.0% agarose: resolves 0.25-10 kb; 2.0% agarose: resolves 0.1-2 kb (best for the 100-500 bp range); 3-4% agarose: resolves very small fragments (<100 bp) but these concentrations make brittle gels. For very fine resolution of small fragments, polyacrylamide gels (PAGE) are used instead of agarose. The optimal agarose percentage is the one where the target size range falls in the linear portion of the log(size) vs. distance relationship.

questions.question: Site-directed mutagenesis allows researchers to make specific changes to a gene's DNA sequence. What is the most common modern method for introducing point mutations?
options: Random chemical mutagenesis followed by screening
Crossing organisms with different alleles
Exposing cells to UV radiation and selecting for mutants
PCR-based mutagenesis using primers containing the desired mutation
questions.explanation: PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis (e.g., QuikChange method) uses oligonucleotide primers that contain the desired mutation. The primers are complementary to the template plasmid except at the mutation site. PCR amplification with high-fidelity polymerase creates a mutant copy of the entire plasmid. The methylated parental (template) DNA is then digested with DpnI (which cuts only methylated DNA), leaving only the newly synthesized mutant plasmid. This method is rapid, efficient, and allows precise introduction of point mutations, insertions, or deletions at any desired position. More recently, CRISPR-based methods can introduce specific mutations in vivo.

questions.question: A researcher designs primers for PCR amplification. The forward primer is 5'-ATCGATCGATCG-3' (12 nt) and the reverse primer is 5'-TAGCTAGCTAGCTAGCTAGC-3' (20 nt). What is a potential problem with this primer pair?
options: The primers have significantly different lengths and likely different melting temperatures (Tm), which may cause one primer to anneal poorly at the chosen annealing temperature
Both primers are too long for PCR
Primers cannot contain the sequence ATCG
PCR requires only one primer, not two
questions.explanation: Optimal PCR requires that both primers have similar melting temperatures (Tm within 2-5°C of each other) so they both anneal efficiently at the same annealing temperature. A 12-nt primer will have a significantly lower Tm than a 20-nt primer, meaning: at a low annealing temperature (suitable for the short primer), the long primer may bind non-specifically; at a high annealing temperature (suitable for the long primer), the short primer may not bind at all. Good PCR primer design guidelines include: 18-25 nt length, 40-60% GC content, matched Tm (within 5°C), no self-complementarity (avoiding primer dimers), and no secondary structure.

questions.question: Microarray (DNA chip) technology allows simultaneous measurement of expression levels for thousands of genes. What does a microarray hybridization experiment actually detect?
options: The relative abundance of mRNA molecules from a sample, by hybridization of fluorescently labeled cDNA to immobilized DNA probes
The protein products of genes
The DNA sequence of genes
The methylation status of all genes
questions.explanation: DNA microarrays contain thousands of gene-specific DNA sequences (probes) spotted or synthesized at defined positions on a glass slide or chip. In a typical gene expression experiment: (1) mRNA is extracted from the sample, (2) converted to cDNA, (3) fluorescently labeled (e.g., Cy3 green for control, Cy5 red for treatment), and (4) hybridized to the array. The fluorescence intensity at each probe location reflects the abundance of the corresponding mRNA. Two-color experiments (competitive hybridization) allow direct comparison between conditions. While largely superseded by RNA-seq for gene expression profiling, microarrays remain valuable for SNP genotyping, comparative genomic hybridization (CGH), and specific applications.

questions.question: Electroporation is used in molecular biology to introduce DNA into cells. What physical principle does electroporation exploit?
options: DNA naturally diffuses through cell membranes
Electroporation uses magnetic fields to attract DNA-coated particles into cells
Electric current synthesizes new DNA within the cell
Brief high-voltage electrical pulses create transient pores in the cell membrane, allowing DNA to enter the cell
questions.explanation: Electroporation uses brief (microsecond to millisecond) high-voltage electrical pulses (typically 200-2,500 V for mammalian cells) to create transient nanometer-scale pores in the lipid bilayer of cell membranes. During the brief period when pores are open, exogenous DNA in the surrounding medium can enter the cell. After the pulse, the pores reseal and the cell recovers. Electroporation is widely used because it works with many cell types (bacteria, yeast, plant cells, mammalian cells) and can introduce plasmids, linear DNA, RNA, or proteins. Key parameters that must be optimized include field strength, pulse duration, pulse number, and buffer composition.

questions.question: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) identify genetic variants associated with diseases or traits. What type of genetic marker is most commonly used in GWAS?
options: RFLPs (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphisms)
STRs (Short Tandem Repeats)
SNPs (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms) genotyped on high-density arrays
Entire gene sequences determined by Sanger sequencing
questions.explanation: Modern GWAS use SNP arrays (chips) that genotype hundreds of thousands to millions of SNPs across the genome in thousands of individuals. SNPs are the most abundant genetic variants (~1 every 300 bp in the human genome, ~4-5 million per individual), making them ideal for comprehensive genome scanning. The study compares SNP frequencies between affected (case) and unaffected (control) groups. SNPs significantly more common in cases are associated with the trait, and their genomic location points to candidate genes or regulatory regions. GWAS have identified thousands of disease-associated loci, though most individual variants have small effect sizes (odds ratios 1.1-1.5).

questions.question: A researcher uses CRISPR-Cas9 to knock out a gene and observes no phenotypic change. Before concluding the gene is non-functional, what should they verify?
options: Nothing further—the absence of phenotype proves the gene is non-functional
Check if the Cas9 protein was properly folded using X-ray crystallography
Repeat the experiment with a different organism
Confirm successful gene disruption by sequencing the target locus, check for compensatory mechanisms from paralogous genes, and test under multiple environmental conditions
questions.explanation: A negative result (no phenotype) from a gene knockout requires careful validation: (1) Confirm the knockout—sequence the target locus to verify the gene is actually disrupted (frameshift, large deletion). An in-frame deletion may produce a truncated but functional protein. (2) Check for genetic compensation—paralogous genes may compensate for the lost gene's function (genetic redundancy). This is especially common for genes in multigene families. (3) Test multiple conditions—the gene may only be essential under specific environmental stresses, developmental stages, or tissue-specific contexts not tested. (4) Verify at the protein level—Western blot to confirm protein absence. (5) Consider conditional knockouts to bypass developmental lethality that might cause embryonic death before observable phenotypes.

questions.question: Recombinant DNA technology relies on DNA ligase to join DNA fragments. Which chemical bond does DNA ligase form?
options: Hydrogen bonds between base pairs
Glycosidic bonds between sugar and base
Peptide bonds between amino acids
Phosphodiester bonds between the 3'-OH of one nucleotide and the 5'-phosphate of the adjacent nucleotide
questions.explanation: DNA ligase catalyzes the formation of a phosphodiester bond between the 3'-hydroxyl group of one nucleotide and the 5'-phosphate group of the adjacent nucleotide, sealing nicks in the sugar-phosphate backbone. T4 DNA ligase (from bacteriophage T4) is most commonly used in molecular biology because it can ligate both cohesive (sticky) ends and blunt ends (though blunt-end ligation is ~100x less efficient). T4 ligase uses ATP as a cofactor, while E. coli DNA ligase uses NAD⁺. In cloning, ligase joins vector and insert DNA fragments that have compatible ends generated by restriction enzyme digestion.

questions.question: Which technique allows visualization of all chromosomes in a cell simultaneously, with each chromosome pair labeled in a different color?
options: Standard G-banding karyotyping
PCR amplification of centromeric sequences
Spectral karyotyping (SKY) or multiplex FISH (M-FISH)
Southern blot of chromosomal DNA
questions.explanation: Spectral karyotyping (SKY) and multiplex FISH (M-FISH) use combinatorial labeling strategies where probes specific to each chromosome are labeled with different combinations of fluorophores. Using 5-7 different fluorophores in various combinations creates a unique spectral signature for each chromosome, displayed as a different pseudocolor. This allows: (1) identification of chromosomal translocations (a chromosome segment will display the color of its chromosome of origin, even when attached to a different chromosome), (2) detection of complex rearrangements that might be missed by standard G-banding, and (3) identification of marker chromosomes of unknown origin. SKY/M-FISH is particularly valuable in cancer cytogenetics where complex chromosomal rearrangements are common.

questions.question: In Gibson Assembly, multiple DNA fragments are joined in a single isothermal reaction. Which combination of enzymes is used?
options: Restriction enzyme + DNA ligase
Exonuclease + DNA polymerase + DNA ligase working simultaneously at 50°C
Taq polymerase + reverse transcriptase
Topoisomerase + helicase
questions.explanation: Gibson Assembly (Daniel Gibson, 2009) uses three enzymatic activities in a single isothermal reaction at 50°C: (1) T5 exonuclease chews back 5' ends of double-stranded DNA, exposing complementary single-stranded overhangs on adjacent fragments (fragments must share ~20-40 bp of overlapping sequence). (2) Phusion DNA polymerase fills in the single-stranded gaps. (3) Taq DNA ligase seals the nicks, covalently joining the fragments. The reaction is performed in a single tube at 50°C for 15-60 minutes. Gibson Assembly is more versatile than traditional restriction enzyme cloning because it does not require specific restriction sites and can join multiple fragments simultaneously in a defined order.

questions.question: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) can detect specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. Which application of FISH is most important in clinical genetics?
options: Detecting chromosomal microdeletions, duplications, and translocations associated with genetic disorders and cancers
Measuring protein expression levels
Sequencing entire genomes
Measuring enzyme activity in cells
questions.explanation: FISH is a powerful clinical tool for detecting structural chromosomal abnormalities that may be too small for conventional karyotyping: (1) Microdeletions—22q11.2 deletion (DiGeorge syndrome), 15q11-13 deletion (Prader-Willi/Angelman). (2) Translocations—BCR-ABL fusion in chronic myeloid leukemia (Philadelphia chromosome), PML-RARA in acute promyelocytic leukemia. (3) Gene amplifications—HER2/neu amplification in breast cancer (guides treatment decisions). (4) Aneuploidy detection—trisomy 13, 18, 21 in prenatal diagnosis using interphase FISH for rapid results. FISH uses fluorescently labeled DNA probes that hybridize to specific chromosomal regions, allowing visualization under fluorescence microscopy.

questions.question: Bioinformatics tools like BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool) are essential for analyzing DNA and protein sequences. What does BLAST primarily do?
options: Amplifies DNA sequences using PCR
Searches sequence databases for regions of similarity between a query sequence and known sequences, identifying homologs and inferring function
Edits DNA sequences in a text editor
Predicts the three-dimensional structure of proteins from their sequence
questions.explanation: BLAST compares a query sequence (DNA or protein) against a database of known sequences to identify regions of significant similarity (homology). It uses a heuristic algorithm that is much faster than exhaustive alignment methods (like Smith-Waterman). BLAST outputs include: aligned sequences, percent identity, E-value (statistical significance—lower is more significant), and bit score. Applications include: identifying gene function by homology to characterized genes, finding orthologs across species for evolutionary analysis, identifying conserved protein domains, and annotating newly sequenced genomes. Variants include BLASTn (nucleotide), BLASTp (protein), BLASTx (translated nucleotide vs. protein database), and tBLASTn (protein vs. translated nucleotide database).

questions.question: Epigenome editing using catalytically dead Cas9 (dCas9) fused to epigenetic modifiers allows researchers to:
options: Permanently delete genes from the genome
Alter gene expression without changing the DNA sequence, by targeting histone modifications or DNA methylation to specific loci
Amplify genes using PCR
Sequence the entire genome in a single read
questions.explanation: dCas9 (catalytically dead Cas9, mutations D10A/H840A) retains DNA-binding specificity guided by gRNA but cannot cut DNA. By fusing dCas9 to epigenetic effector domains, researchers can target specific epigenetic modifications to desired genomic loci: (1) dCas9-DNMT3A: deposits DNA methylation at promoters, typically silencing genes. (2) dCas9-TET1: removes DNA methylation, potentially activating genes. (3) dCas9-p300: acetylates histones, activating enhancers and promoters. (4) dCas9-KRAB: recruits heterochromatin machinery, silencing genes (CRISPRi). (5) dCas9-VP64: activates transcription (CRISPRa). This allows reversible modulation of gene expression without permanent DNA sequence changes.

questions.question: Phage display technology is used to identify peptides or proteins that bind to specific targets. How does phage display work?
options: Bacteriophages naturally produce all human antibodies
Diverse peptide or antibody sequences are fused to phage coat proteins, and phages displaying peptides that bind the target are selected by biopanning
Phages are used to sequence DNA
Phage display involves displaying chromosomes on phage surfaces
questions.explanation: Phage display (George Smith, 1985; Nobel Prize 2018) works by: (1) inserting a library of random DNA sequences (encoding diverse peptides or antibody fragments) into a phage coat protein gene (usually pIII or pVIII of M13 filamentous phage). (2) When the phage is produced, the foreign peptide is displayed on the phage surface fused to the coat protein. (3) The phage library (10⁸-10¹¹ unique variants) is exposed to an immobilized target molecule. Phages that bind are retained (biopanning), non-binders are washed away, and bound phages are eluted, amplified, and subjected to additional rounds of selection. After 3-5 rounds, high-affinity binders are enriched. This technology is widely used for antibody discovery (therapeutic antibodies like adalimumab) and peptide identification.

questions.question: A restriction map is constructed by comparing single and double digests. When plasmid X (8 kb) is cut with EcoRI alone, two fragments result: 5 kb and 3 kb. When cut with HindIII alone, two fragments result: 6 kb and 2 kb. When cut with both enzymes together, four fragments result: 4 kb, 2 kb, 1 kb, and 1 kb. Where is the HindIII site located relative to the EcoRI sites?
options: The HindIII site is within the 5 kb EcoRI fragment, 4 kb from one EcoRI site and 1 kb from the other
The HindIII site is within the 3 kb EcoRI fragment
The HindIII site coincides with one of the EcoRI sites
The data are inconsistent and cannot produce a valid map
questions.explanation: With EcoRI: 5 kb + 3 kb = 8 kb. With HindIII: 6 kb + 2 kb = 8 kb. Double digest: 4 + 2 + 1 + 1 = 8 kb. Since EcoRI produces 5 and 3 kb fragments, and the double digest produces 4 fragments, HindIII must cut within one of the EcoRI fragments. The 5 kb fragment is split into 4 kb + 1 kb (= 5 kb) by HindIII. The 3 kb fragment becomes the 2 kb + 1 kb fragments? No: 2 + 1 = 3. But then HindIII cuts both EcoRI fragments, giving 4 fragments from 2 HindIII sites. However, we established there are only 2 HindIII sites total. The HindIII site splits the 5 kb EcoRI fragment into 4 kb and 1 kb. The 3 kb and 2 kb remaining fragments come from the arrangement on the circular molecule. Working through the circular map confirms the HindIII site is within the 5 kb EcoRI fragment.

questions.question: What is metagenomics, and why is it important for studying microbial diversity?
options: Sequencing all DNA extracted directly from an environmental sample without culturing, revealing the full diversity of organisms present, including unculturable species
Sequencing a single organism's genome to high accuracy
Comparing the genomes of two closely related species
Studying only the mitochondrial genome of a species
questions.explanation: Metagenomics involves extracting and sequencing all DNA directly from environmental samples (soil, water, gut contents, etc.) without the need to culture individual organisms. This is revolutionary because >99% of environmental microorganisms cannot be cultured using standard laboratory techniques. Metagenomics reveals: (1) the taxonomic diversity of microbial communities (who is there?), (2) the functional potential encoded in community genomes (what can they do?), (3) novel genes and enzymes from uncultured organisms (bioprospecting), and (4) community dynamics in response to environmental changes. Shotgun metagenomics sequences all DNA, while amplicon sequencing (e.g., 16S rRNA gene) focuses on taxonomic identification.

questions.question: The CRISPR-Cas9 system requires a PAM (Protospacer Adjacent Motif) sequence adjacent to the target site. What is the primary biological function of the PAM requirement?
options: PAM increases the cutting efficiency of Cas9
PAM is required for Cas9 protein folding
PAM distinguishes foreign DNA (targets) from the host's own CRISPR array, preventing autoimmunity—the host CRISPR locus lacks PAM sequences adjacent to spacers
PAM provides the energy source for DNA cleavage
questions.explanation: The PAM sequence serves as a self vs. non-self discrimination mechanism in the bacterial CRISPR immune system. Spacer sequences in the host's CRISPR array are identical to target sequences in invading phages/plasmids, which could potentially cause self-targeting. However, the spacers in the CRISPR array are NOT flanked by PAM sequences, while the same sequences in foreign DNA are. Cas9 first recognizes the PAM on the target DNA before checking for gRNA complementarity. Since the host CRISPR locus lacks PAMs adjacent to its spacers, self-cleavage is prevented. This elegant self/non-self discrimination mechanism prevents autoimmune destruction of the bacterial chromosome while allowing destruction of matching foreign DNA.

questions.question: Ethical concerns about human germline editing using CRISPR-Cas9 primarily center on which issue?
options: Germline edits are technically impossible
Germline edits are heritable, affecting all future generations, raising concerns about consent, equity, unintended consequences, and the potential for eugenics
Germline editing only affects the individual being treated
CRISPR-Cas9 cannot target human genes
questions.explanation: Human germline editing (modifying eggs, sperm, or embryos) is controversial because changes are heritable—they are passed to all descendants, who cannot consent to the modification. Key ethical concerns include: (1) Consent—future generations cannot agree to irreversible genetic changes. (2) Safety—off-target mutations could have unpredictable effects that propagate through generations. (3) Equity—access to genetic enhancement could exacerbate social inequality. (4) Eugenics—the potential for selecting 'desirable' traits raises historical parallels to eugenics programs. (5) Unknown consequences—we lack full understanding of gene interactions and pleiotropy. Somatic gene therapy (affecting only the individual) is less controversial because changes are not inherited. The 2018 CRISPR-baby case (He Jiankui) highlighted these concerns.

questions.question: Plasmid vectors used for protein expression in E. coli typically contain an inducible promoter. The lac promoter/operator system uses IPTG (isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside) as an inducer. Why is IPTG used instead of lactose?
options: IPTG is cheaper than lactose
IPTG binds the lac repressor and relieves repression, but unlike lactose it is not metabolized by the cell, maintaining constant induction levels
IPTG is a stronger inducer than lactose
IPTG activates RNA polymerase directly
questions.explanation: IPTG is a non-metabolizable analog of allolactose (the natural inducer of the lac operon). IPTG binds to the lac repressor protein, causing a conformational change that releases the repressor from the operator, allowing transcription. The key advantage of IPTG over lactose is that IPTG is not broken down by β-galactosidase, so its intracellular concentration remains constant throughout the experiment, providing stable, consistent induction. Lactose, in contrast, is metabolized by the cell, causing its concentration to decrease over time and leading to variable, difficult-to-control expression levels. IPTG also penetrates cells without requiring a transporter and is not subject to catabolite repression.

questions.question: What is the principle behind the blue-white screening method used to identify recombinant clones in molecular cloning?
options: Recombinant cells turn blue due to expression of the foreign gene
White colonies contain more DNA than blue colonies

Insertion of foreign DNA into the lacZ gene within the multiple cloning site disrupts β-galactosidase activity, so recombinant colonies remain white while non-recombinant colonies turn blue on X-gal plates
The color indicates antibiotic resistance status
questions.explanation: Blue-white screening exploits insertional inactivation of the lacZ gene. The vector contains the lacZ alpha-peptide gene with a multiple cloning site (MCS) embedded within it. (1) Non-recombinant vectors (no insert): the lacZ gene remains intact, producing functional β-galactosidase alpha-peptide. This complements the host's β-galactosidase omega-peptide (alpha-complementation), producing active enzyme that cleaves X-gal (5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-β-D-galactoside), releasing a blue precipitate → blue colonies. (2) Recombinant vectors (insert in MCS): the insert disrupts the lacZ reading frame, no functional alpha-peptide is produced, X-gal is not cleaved → white colonies. IPTG is added to induce lacZ expression.

questions.question: A researcher wants to study the regulatory elements controlling expression of a specific gene. Which experimental approach would map the promoter and enhancer regions?
options: PCR amplification of the coding sequence
Restriction enzyme digestion of the genomic locus
Western blot analysis of the protein product
Reporter gene assays using a series of deletion constructs, where different upstream regions are fused to a reporter gene (luciferase/GFP) and transfected into cells
questions.explanation: Reporter gene deletion analysis is the gold standard for mapping regulatory elements: (1) Clone the upstream region of the gene of interest in front of a reporter gene (luciferase, GFP, β-galactosidase). (2) Create a series of 5' deletion constructs (progressively removing upstream sequence). (3) Transfect each construct into appropriate cells and measure reporter activity. (4) A significant drop in reporter expression when a specific region is deleted indicates that region contains an essential regulatory element. This approach can identify promoters, enhancers, silencers, and other cis-regulatory elements. Complementary approaches include DNase footprinting, EMSA, ChIP (chromatin immunoprecipitation), and ATAC-seq.

questions.question: Comparative genomics has revealed that the proportion of the genome encoding proteins varies dramatically across species. Which organism has the highest proportion of its genome devoted to protein-coding sequences?
options: Humans (~1.5% protein-coding)
Pufferfish (Fugu rubripes, ~10% protein-coding)
Corn (Zea mays, ~3% protein-coding)
E. coli (~87% protein-coding)
questions.explanation: Bacteria like E. coli have compact genomes where approximately 87% of the DNA encodes proteins, with minimal intergenic and non-coding sequences. As genome complexity increases, the proportion of protein-coding DNA generally decreases: the pufferfish Fugu has one of the most compact vertebrate genomes (~10% coding); most mammals including humans have only ~1.5% protein-coding DNA; and some plants like corn have even lower proportions (~3%) due to massive genome expansion by transposable elements. The human genome (~3.2 billion bp) encodes ~20,000 genes in ~1.5% of its sequence; the remaining ~98.5% consists of introns, regulatory sequences, repetitive elements, and other non-coding DNA.

questions.question: Whole-exome sequencing (WES) focuses on the protein-coding regions of the genome (~1-2% of total DNA). Why might a clinician choose WES over whole-genome sequencing (WGS) for diagnosing a genetic disease?
options: WES is always more accurate than WGS
WES can detect structural variants better than WGS
WES is less expensive and faster to analyze, while capturing the majority of known disease-causing variants since ~85% of disease-causing mutations occur in coding regions
WES sequences all non-coding regulatory regions
questions.explanation: WES is often preferred clinically because: (1) Cost—sequencing only ~2% of the genome is significantly cheaper than WGS. (2) Data analysis—much smaller datasets are faster to analyze and interpret. (3) Clinical utility—approximately 85% of known disease-causing mutations are in exons (protein-coding regions), so WES captures the vast majority of clinically relevant variants. However, WES misses: variants in regulatory regions, deep intronic splice variants, structural variants, repeat expansions, and mitochondrial DNA mutations. WGS is becoming more common as costs decrease and analytical methods improve, but WES remains the first-line sequencing approach for many clinical genetic diagnoses.

questions.question: Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) is used to study protein-DNA interactions. What information does ChIP-seq provide?
options: The complete DNA sequence of a genome
The methylation status of CpG islands
The expression levels of all genes
The specific genomic locations where a protein of interest (e.g., transcription factor, modified histone) binds to DNA across the entire genome
questions.explanation: ChIP-seq maps the genome-wide binding sites of specific proteins: (1) Cross-link proteins to DNA in living cells (formaldehyde). (2) Fragment chromatin by sonication. (3) Immunoprecipitate protein-DNA complexes using an antibody specific to the protein of interest (transcription factor, histone modification like H3K4me3, H3K27ac). (4) Reverse cross-links and purify the immunoprecipitated DNA. (5) Sequence the enriched DNA fragments by NGS. (6) Map reads to the genome to identify peaks of enrichment indicating binding sites. ChIP-seq has been instrumental in mapping transcription factor binding sites, histone modification patterns, and the epigenomic landscape across cell types and conditions.

questions.question: Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) has revolutionized our understanding of cellular heterogeneity. What is the key advantage of scRNA-seq over bulk RNA-seq?
options: scRNA-seq reveals gene expression profiles of individual cells, enabling identification of rare cell types, cell states, and developmental trajectories that are averaged out in bulk analysis
scRNA-seq is cheaper per sample
scRNA-seq provides longer read lengths
scRNA-seq sequences DNA rather than RNA
questions.explanation: scRNA-seq analyzes the transcriptome of individual cells rather than averaging across thousands to millions of cells (as in bulk RNA-seq). Key advantages include: (1) Identifying rare cell types—even cells comprising <1% of a population can be characterized. (2) Revealing cellular heterogeneity—discovering previously unknown cell subtypes and states within seemingly homogeneous tissues. (3) Trajectory analysis—inferring developmental pathways and cell fate decisions (pseudotime). (4) Cell atlas construction—comprehensive catalogs of cell types in organs/organisms (Human Cell Atlas project). Technologies include droplet-based methods (10x Genomics), plate-based methods (Smart-seq2), and combinatorial indexing (sci-RNA-seq). scRNA-seq typically captures 1,000-5,000 genes per cell from thousands to millions of cells.

questions.question: CRISPR-Cas13 differs from CRISPR-Cas9 in its target substrate. What does Cas13 target, and what potential application does this enable?
options: Cas13 targets DNA and enables genome editing
Cas13 targets single-stranded RNA, enabling transcript knockdown, RNA editing, and nucleic acid-based diagnostics without altering the genome
Cas13 targets proteins for degradation
Cas13 targets carbohydrates on cell surfaces
questions.explanation: Cas13 is an RNA-guided RNA endonuclease—it targets single-stranded RNA rather than DNA. This enables: (1) Programmable RNA knockdown—reducing transcript levels without permanently altering the genome (reversible). (2) RNA editing—Cas13 fused to ADAR (adenosine deaminase acting on RNA) can perform A-to-I editing on specific RNA transcripts. (3) Diagnostics—the SHERLOCK platform exploits Cas13's collateral cleavage activity (upon target recognition, Cas13 non-specifically cleaves nearby ssRNAs, including fluorescent reporters) for ultrasensitive nucleic acid detection of pathogens. (4) RNA tracking—catalytically dead dCas13 fused to fluorescent proteins can track specific RNAs in living cells.

questions.question: A researcher uses RT-qPCR to measure expression of Gene X relative to a housekeeping gene (GAPDH). In control cells, Gene X Ct = 25 and GAPDH Ct = 18. In treated cells, Gene X Ct = 22 and GAPDH Ct = 18. Calculate the fold change in Gene X expression using the ΔΔCt method.
options: 2-fold increase
4-fold increase
8-fold increase
No change
questions.explanation: ΔΔCt method: (1) ΔCt_control = Ct(Gene X) - Ct(GAPDH) = 25 - 18 = 7. (2) ΔCt_treated = 22 - 18 = 4. (3) ΔΔCt = ΔCt_treated - ΔCt_control = 4 - 7 = -3. (4) Fold change = 2^(-ΔΔCt) = 2^(-(-3)) = 2³ = 8. Gene X expression is 8-fold higher in treated cells compared to control cells. The lower Ct value in treated cells (22 vs. 25) indicates more template (earlier crossing of the fluorescence threshold). Each 1-Ct difference represents approximately a 2-fold change in starting template quantity, so a 3-Ct reduction corresponds to 2³ = 8-fold increase.

questions.question: Optogenetics combines genetic engineering with optics to control neuronal activity. Which component is essential for optogenetic control of neurons?
options: Fluorescent proteins like GFP for visualization
Chemical neurotransmitter analogs
Light-sensitive ion channels (e.g., channelrhodopsin-2) genetically expressed in target neurons, which can be activated or inhibited by specific wavelengths of light
Radioactive tracers that target neurons
questions.explanation: Optogenetics requires: (1) Genetic targeting—expressing a light-sensitive protein (opsin) in specific neuron types using genetic tools (viral vectors, transgenic lines). (2) Light delivery—implanting fiber optics to deliver light to deep brain regions. Key opsins include: channelrhodopsin-2 (ChR2, blue light-activated cation channel → neuronal excitation), halorhodopsin (NpHR, yellow light-activated chloride pump → neuronal inhibition), and archaerhodopsin (Arch, green light-activated proton pump → inhibition). By combining cell-type-specific expression with temporally precise light pulses (millisecond resolution), researchers can causally link specific neuronal activity patterns to behaviors—something impossible with pharmacological or lesion approaches.

questions.question: Long-read sequencing technologies (Pacific Biosciences SMRT, Oxford Nanopore) can produce reads of 10-100+ kb. What specific advantage does this provide over short-read sequencing?
options: Long reads are more accurate per base
Long reads do not require any library preparation
Long reads are less expensive per base
Long reads can span repetitive regions and structural variants that are unresolvable with short reads, improving genome assembly continuity
questions.explanation: Long reads (10-100+ kb) provide critical advantages for: (1) Resolving repetitive regions—the human genome contains many repeats longer than short reads (e.g., centromeric satellite DNA, segmental duplications, transposable elements), causing ambiguous short-read mapping. Long reads can span these repeats, providing unique flanking sequences for placement. (2) Detecting structural variants—large insertions, deletions, inversions, and translocations that are missed by short reads. (3) Phasing—determining which variants are on the same chromosome (haplotype). (4) Assembly continuity—reducing the number of contigs and gaps in genome assemblies. (5) Direct detection of base modifications (methylation) without bisulfite conversion. The tradeoff is generally higher per-base error rates, though this has improved significantly.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine which of 20,000 genes are essential for cell viability in a human cancer cell line. Which high-throughput CRISPR-based approach is most suitable?
options: Individually knocking out each gene one at a time
A genome-wide CRISPR knockout screen using a pooled sgRNA library, followed by identifying which guide RNAs are depleted from the surviving population
RNA-seq to measure gene expression levels
Proteomics to quantify all proteins
questions.explanation: Genome-wide CRISPR screens use pooled lentiviral sgRNA libraries (targeting every gene with 4-10 guides each) to systematically disrupt genes across a cell population: (1) Transduce cells at low MOI (one guide per cell). (2) Culture under selection (viability screen) or specific conditions (phenotypic screen). (3) Sequence the integrated guides from surviving cells. (4) Guides targeting essential genes are depleted (cells with those knockouts die), while guides targeting non-essential genes remain. (5) Computational analysis (MAGeCK, BAGEL) identifies essential genes. This approach can screen all ~20,000 genes simultaneously in a single experiment. Variations include CRISPRi (inhibition) and CRISPRa (activation) screens for more nuanced loss/gain-of-function studies.

questions.question: Antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) are synthetic single-stranded DNA or RNA molecules used therapeutically. How do ASOs reduce target gene expression?
options: ASOs activate transcription of the target gene
ASOs bind to the protein product and cause its degradation
ASOs integrate into the genome and delete the target gene
ASOs bind complementary mRNA by Watson-Crick base pairing, blocking translation or triggering RNase H-mediated mRNA degradation
questions.explanation: ASOs work through several mechanisms: (1) RNase H recruitment—DNA-based ASOs form RNA:DNA heteroduplexes with target mRNA, recruiting RNase H which cleaves the RNA strand, destroying the mRNA. (2) Steric blocking—some ASOs (especially those with 2'-modified sugars) physically block ribosome scanning or splicing machinery without triggering RNase H. (3) Splice modulation—ASOs targeting splice sites can alter pre-mRNA splicing, either skipping exons (exon skipping in Duchenne muscular dystrophy: eteplirsen) or including exons normally skipped. Chemical modifications (phosphorothioate backbone, 2'-O-methyl, locked nucleic acids) improve stability, binding affinity, and pharmacokinetics. FDA-approved ASO drugs include nusinersen (SMA), mipomersen (hypercholesterolemia), and inotersen (TTR amyloidosis).

questions.question: Molecular cloning often uses blue-white screening combined with antibiotic selection. If a researcher plates transformed E. coli on LB agar containing ampicillin, IPTG, and X-gal, what does each component select for?
options: Ampicillin selects for cells containing the plasmid; IPTG induces lacZ expression; X-gal is the substrate that produces blue color when cleaved by β-galactosidase
Ampicillin kills all bacteria; IPTG provides a carbon source; X-gal provides nitrogen
Ampicillin induces gene expression; IPTG is an antibiotic; X-gal is a vitamin
All three components are required for bacterial growth
questions.explanation: The three-component screening system works together: (1) Ampicillin in the medium kills non-transformed cells (only cells containing the ampicillin-resistance plasmid survive). (2) IPTG induces expression of the lacZ alpha-peptide gene on the plasmid—without IPTG, lacZ would not be expressed and all colonies would be white regardless of insert status. (3) X-gal is a chromogenic substrate for β-galactosidase—functional enzyme (in non-recombinant clones) cleaves X-gal to produce an insoluble blue precipitate, while disrupted lacZ (in recombinant clones with insert) cannot cleave X-gal, leaving colonies white. Result: only white colonies on ampicillin plates are likely recombinant clones.

questions.question: The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can theoretically amplify a single molecule of DNA. After 30 cycles of PCR with 100% efficiency, approximately how many copies of the target sequence would be produced from a single template molecule?
options: 30 copies
60 copies
About 1 billion (10⁹) copies
About 1 million (10⁶) copies
questions.explanation: PCR amplification is exponential: after n cycles, the number of copies = 2ⁿ (assuming 100% efficiency from a single template). After 30 cycles: 2³⁰ = 1,073,741,824 ≈ 10⁹ (about 1 billion copies). This exponential amplification is what makes PCR so powerful—from a single DNA molecule, detectable quantities of DNA can be generated in about 2-3 hours. In practice, efficiency is less than 100% (typically 90-105%), so actual yields are somewhat lower. The amplification power of PCR also means that contamination with even a few molecules of non-target DNA can produce false positives, necessitating careful laboratory procedures.

questions.question: Transgenic animals can be created by microinjecting DNA constructs into fertilized eggs. In mice, the pronucleus of a recently fertilized oocyte is injected. Which pronucleus is typically targeted and why?
options: The male pronucleus, because it is larger (more decondensed) and easier to visualize and inject
The female pronucleus, because it is larger and easier to inject
Both pronuclei must be injected simultaneously
Neither pronucleus—DNA is injected into the cytoplasm only
questions.explanation: In pronuclear microinjection for generating transgenic mice, DNA is injected into the male pronucleus because: (1) it is larger than the female pronucleus at the time of injection (shortly after fertilization, the male pronucleus undergoes protamine-to-histone replacement and decondensation, making it visibly larger), (2) the larger size makes it easier to target with the microinjection needle, and (3) the more decondensed chromatin may facilitate DNA integration. The injected DNA integrates randomly into the genome (transgene insertion). Typically 10-30% of surviving pups will carry the transgene. This approach has largely been supplemented by CRISPR-based methods for generating genetically modified mice.

questions.question: What is the principle behind DNA methylation analysis using bisulfite sequencing?
options: Bisulfite converts methylated cytosines to thymine, allowing detection by sequencing

Bisulfite converts unmethylated cytosines to uracil (read as thymine after PCR), while methylated cytosines are protected and remain as cytosine—comparison to the reference sequence reveals methylation status
Bisulfite directly sequences methylated DNA without conversion
Bisulfite removes all cytosines regardless of methylation status
questions.explanation: Bisulfite treatment is the gold standard for single-nucleotide-resolution DNA methylation analysis: (1) Sodium bisulfite deaminates unmethylated cytosine to uracil (which is read as thymine after PCR amplification). (2) 5-methylcytosine (5mC) is resistant to bisulfite conversion and remains as cytosine. (3) By sequencing bisulfite-treated DNA and comparing to the reference genome, every position where C is retained (instead of converting to T) indicates a methylated cytosine. (4) This can be applied genome-wide (whole-genome bisulfite sequencing, WGBS) or targeted (reduced representation bisulfite sequencing, RRBS, focusing on CpG-rich regions). Limitations include degradation of DNA during harsh bisulfite treatment and inability to distinguish 5mC from 5-hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) without additional methods.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about biotechnology applications:
I. Transgenic organisms contain DNA from another species introduced through genetic engineering
II. Golden rice was engineered to produce beta-carotene (provitamin A) to address vitamin A deficiency
III. Bt crops produce Bacillus thuringiensis toxin that kills insect pests
IV. All genetically modified organisms are produced using CRISPR-Cas9
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: Transgenic organisms contain foreign DNA (transgenes) from another species. Examples include GFP-expressing mice (jellyfish gene), Bt crops (bacterial gene), and transgenic salmon (growth hormone gene). II. TRUE: Golden rice was engineered by inserting daffodil phytoene synthase and bacterial carotene desaturase genes into rice, enabling beta-carotene production in the endosperm to combat vitamin A deficiency. III. TRUE: Bt crops (corn, cotton, soybean) express the Cry protein from Bacillus thuringiensis, which forms pores in insect gut membranes, killing specific insect pests while being non-toxic to mammals. IV. FALSE: GMOs have been produced since the 1970s using various methods including Agrobacterium-mediated transformation, biolistics (gene gun), microinjection, and electroporation—long before CRISPR-Cas9 was developed (2012).

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about cloning vectors:
I. A cloning vector must contain an origin of replication (ori) to replicate in host cells
II. Selectable markers (e.g., antibiotic resistance) allow identification of cells that have taken up the vector
III. A multiple cloning site (polylinker) contains several unique restriction enzyme recognition sequences for inserting foreign DNA
IV. All cloning vectors can accept DNA inserts larger than 500 kb
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: All cloning vectors require an origin of replication for autonomous replication in the host cell. Plasmid vectors use bacterial ori sequences; YACs include yeast centromere and telomere sequences. II. TRUE: Selectable markers (ampicillin resistance, kanamycin resistance, URA3 in yeast) are essential for identifying cells that have taken up the vector, as transformation efficiency is typically low. III. TRUE: The multiple cloning site (MCS) or polylinker is a short DNA segment containing multiple unique restriction sites, allowing researchers to choose compatible enzymes for directional cloning. IV. FALSE: Insert capacity varies greatly: plasmids (1-10 kb), cosmids (~35-45 kb), BACs (100-300 kb), and only YACs can accept inserts >500 kb (up to ~2 Mb). Most vectors have upper insert size limits.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about gene therapy:
I. Ex vivo gene therapy involves modifying cells outside the body and then transplanting them back into the patient
II. In vivo gene therapy delivers the therapeutic gene directly to cells within the patient's body
III. Gene therapy has successfully cured some patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)
IV. Gene therapy carries no risk of adverse effects such as insertional mutagenesis
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: Ex vivo gene therapy removes cells from the patient (e.g., hematopoietic stem cells), genetically modifies them in culture, and returns them to the patient. Examples include CAR-T cell therapy and ex vivo gene correction for SCID. II. TRUE: In vivo gene therapy delivers therapeutic genes directly to target tissues using viral vectors (AAV, lentivirus) or non-viral delivery systems. Examples include Luxturna (AAV for RPE65 mutation causing blindness) and Zolgensma (AAV for spinal muscular atrophy). III. TRUE: Gene therapy has cured SCID-X1 (bubble boy disease) in clinical trials, with patients maintaining functional immune systems years after treatment. IV. FALSE: Gene therapy carries risks including insertional mutagenesis (vector integration near oncogenes can cause cancer, as occurred in early SCID trials), immune responses to viral vectors, off-target effects, and variable transgene expression.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about emerging biotechnologies:
I. Base editing can convert one DNA base to another (e.g., C to T) without creating double-strand breaks
II. Prime editing can install any type of point mutation, small insertion, or deletion without double-strand breaks or donor DNA
III. Organoids are three-dimensional cell cultures that recapitulate some structural and functional features of organs
IV. All CRISPR applications require cutting both strands of DNA
options: TTTF
TTTT
TFTT
TFTF
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: Base editors (CBE = cytidine base editor, C→T; ABE = adenine base editor, A→G) use nickase Cas9 fused to deaminase enzymes to directly convert one base to another without double-strand breaks. II. TRUE: Prime editing (PE) uses Cas9 nickase fused to reverse transcriptase and a prime editing guide RNA (pegRNA) that contains both the target-binding sequence and a template for the desired edit. It can install any single-base change, small insertions (up to ~40 bp), or deletions without DSBs or external donor DNA. III. TRUE: Organoids are self-organizing 3D structures grown from stem cells that mimic organ architecture and function (brain organoids, intestinal organoids, kidney organoids). IV. FALSE: Many CRISPR applications (CRISPRi/a using dCas9, base editing, prime editing, RNA targeting with Cas13, epigenome editing) do not require double-strand DNA breaks.
